title: 112_s330
content: The "Consumer Recall Protection Act of 2011" prohibits the sale of recalled products. The "Consumer Recall Protection Act of 2011" defines a covered product as a motor vehicle, food, drugs, devices, cosmetics, biological product, or consumer product. The "Consumer Recall Protection Act of 2011" defines a covered product as a motor vehicle, food, drugs, devices, cosmetics, biological product, or consumer product. The Act also specifies that a covered product includes meat, poultry, eggs, and their respective products as defined in specific sections of related Acts. Recall, in this context, refers to a situation where the Secretary of Transportation determines that a covered product has a defect related to motor vehicle safety or does not comply with applicable safety standards. The "Consumer Recall Protection Act of 2011" requires compliance with motor vehicle safety standards, notification, and remedy for defects or noncompliance. For devices and infant formula, orders or recalls under specific sections of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act are mandated. The "Consumer Recall Protection Act of 2011" mandates recalls of infant formula in accordance with specific sections of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, as well as orders under the Public Health Service Act for certain products. The "Consumer Recall Protection Act of 2011" requires recalls of covered products under specific laws such as the Consumer Product Safety Act, Federal Meat Inspection Act, Poultry Products Inspection Act, and Egg Products Inspection Act. It prohibits the sale of recalled products to consumers. The "Consumer Recall Protection Act of 2011" prohibits the sale of recalled products to consumers unless the defect has been remedied and the consumer has been notified of the recall, defect, and remedy. Violations of this prohibition are treated as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Federal Trade Commission enforces the provisions of the Consumer Recall Protection Act in the same manner as the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Commission also prescribes necessary regulations for enforcement. The Consumer Product Safety Commission, in collaboration with other agencies, maintains a list of recalled products. The Consumer Product Safety Commission, in collaboration with other agencies, establishes and maintains a searchable list of covered products subject to recall for public access.
